content.webTitle: TV tonight: those little lies just keep on getting bigger

fields.headline: TV tonight: those little lies just keep on getting bigger
fields.bodyText: Big Little Lies 9pm, Sky Atlantic The cliffhanger moment from the close of episode one – when new arrival Mary whispered: “So who are we going to kill?” into the ear of a sobbing Celeste – is put to one side this week. Instead, the Californian conspiracy drama concentrates on domestic dilemmas helpfully contextualised by flashbacks illuminating past traumatic ordeals endured by the Monterey Five. Renata’s world comes tumbling down around her, Celeste opens up to her therapist and Mary stokes her war with Madeline. Bigger lies but less mystique. Mike Bradley The Family Brain Games 8pm, BBC Two In “the ultimate test of cross-generational brainpower”, Dara Ó Briain puts the first pair of eight unreasonably bright British families to the test in a series of fiendish challenges, all observed by a neuroscientist assessing evidence of collective intelligence. A fun gameshow for geeks. Nightly until Thursday. MB Thatcher: A Very British Revolution 9pm, BBC Two Disenchantment in middle England heralds the end of Thatcher’s time in power. Any parallels with current Tory woes are left for the viewers to note, as men – in grey suits and otherwise – recount those dramatic days. Michael Heseltine, Nigel Lawson and Malcolm Rifkind all feature. Ellen E Jones Year of the Rabbit 10pm, Channel 4 DI Rabbit is at his rascally best as Andy Riley and Kevin Cecil’s riotous Victorian police spoof finds him on the trail of a killer known as the Brick Man. At last we learn more about Keeley Hawes’s mysterious character, who steps out of the shadows long enough to lure would-be “ladyfilth” Mabel into her orbit. MB Me and My Sex Doll: The Sex Business 10pm, Channel 5 Highly unenlightening doc focusing on the rising popularity of human-esque sex toys. Along the way, mannequin merchant Jade admits being somewhat “jaded” by the industry, while Reggie, who repairs sex dolls, straightfacedly claims that “the best way to start a business is to fill a hole”. Hannah J Davies My Wild Animal Baby 10pm, More4 You’ve heard of the people raised by wild animals but what about the wild animals raised by people? This new series follows the brave folk who have opened their homes to non-human offspring, kicking off with Mark and Dawn Dumas from Canada, who adopted polar bear cub Agee when she was just eight weeks old. HJD Film choice Farewell, My Lovely, 6am, Movies4Men This quintessential 1940s film noir stars Dick Powell as private eye Philip Marlowe, narrating the bleak tale in flashback. It is lovingly crafted by Edward Dmytryk, with sharp dialogue and some indelible performances, as Mike Mazurki’s gangster sets Marlowe after Claire Trevor’s marvellous Velma. Paul Howlett Sport choice World Cup Cricket: West Indies v Bangladesh, 10am, Sky Sports Cricket Taunton’s County Ground hosts the group stage encounter. Tennis: Queen’s, 1pm, BBC Two Day one of the Wimbledon warm-up tournament. Women’s World Cup Football: Nigeria v France 7.45pm, BBC Four The hosts’ final group game.
